text: I'm more versed in B2B with avg contract size ranging from $1,000 to $5,000 monthly. What type of content is fitting for enterprise sized customers? Trying to learn to support some young companies that are trying to go after bigger fish.

elements.text: I'm more versed in B2B with avg contract size ranging from $1,000 to $5,000 monthly. What type of content is fitting for enterprise sized customers? Trying to learn to support some young companies that are trying to go after bigger fish.

text:
<@U013VC9V325> This is a great question. I believe there's a big difference in the kind of content that supports the kinds of sales you're asking about. I'm talking here about sales with an ACV of $100,000 and up.

The kind of content you need to create depends mostly on the complexity of the customer's decision process and the kinds of questions they are likely to ask throughout it.

I also depends on whether Marketing will throw MQLs over the wall for Sales to close, or whether Marketing and Sales agree that content has something to contribute toward shortening sales cycles.

I don't want to go on and on here and risk boring you.

This is a big topic, and I'm passionate about it.  In my experience, few B2B marketers know anything about how to support complex sales. They usually leave that challenge to Sales.

Please tell me how interested you are, and I'll respond with what I hope is the right amount of detail.

elements.text:

The kind of content you need to create depends mostly on the complexity of the customer's decision process and the kinds of questions they are likely to ask throughout it.

I also depends on whether Marketing will throw MQLs over the wall for Sales to close, or whether Marketing and Sales agree that content has something to contribute toward shortening sales cycles.

I don't want to go on and on here and risk boring you.

This is a big topic, and I'm passionate about it.  In my experience, few B2B marketers know anything about how to support complex sales. They usually leave that challenge to Sales.

Please tell me how interested you are, and I'll respond with what I hope is the right amount of detail.

text: Yea, I’d welcome more detail / learning more.

elements.text: Yea, I’d welcome more detail / learning more.

text: I’m working with a couple groups and producing “they ask, you answer” content in the school of thought of Marcus Sheridan but wondering how to approach content for the big banks and health centers (fintech and health tech respectively) that they aspire to lasso.

elements.text: I’m working with a couple groups and producing “they ask, you answer” content in the school of thought of Marcus Sheridan but wondering how to approach content for the big banks and health centers (fintech and health tech respectively) that they aspire to lasso.

text: I've worked mostly in the 30K+ range, all the way up to huge enterprise deals in the millions of dollars. I think it takes a while to understand how long and complex the sales cycles are, and develop real empathy for your sales team, who might have to manage buying committees of dozens of even hundreds of people in dozens of different roles around the world. It's a slow burn. Your company might go to bat 2 or 3 times before they buy. You have to nurture. And you have to prove why every single persona needs what you're selling. You have to slice that content razor thin sometimes because if they even get a whiff of generality they ain't having it.

elements.text: I've worked mostly in the 30K+ range, all the way up to huge enterprise deals in the millions of dollars. I think it takes a while to understand how long and complex the sales cycles are, and develop real empathy for your sales team, who might have to manage buying committees of dozens of even hundreds of people in dozens of different roles around the world. It's a slow burn. Your company might go to bat 2 or 3 times before they buy. You have to nurture. And you have to prove why every single persona needs what you're selling. You have to slice that content razor thin sometimes because if they even get a whiff of generality they ain't having it.

text: Instead of a few interactions' worth of content, you start thinking on the scale of a few interactions per month for every persona for 1-2 years.

elements.text: Instead of a few interactions' worth of content, you start thinking on the scale of a few interactions per month for every persona for 1-2 years.

text: <@U013VC9V325> love that you're working on They Ask, You Answer content. I'm a big fan of Marcus Sheridan, and I think his ideas deserve a lot more consideration than they seem to get from marketers who work with complex sales. In complex buying decisions, buyers have many times more questions than they do in simpler buying decisions. The key is to understand all their questions and concerns and to address them with content.

elements.text: love that you're working on They Ask, You Answer content. I'm a big fan of Marcus Sheridan, and I think his ideas deserve a lot more consideration than they seem to get from marketers who work with complex sales. In complex buying decisions, buyers have many times more questions than they do in simpler buying decisions. The key is to understand all their questions and concerns and to address them with content.

text:
<@URAV154AV> Thanks for you insights. I agree with you entirely. I think part of the problem is that we have no concept in our marketing and sales lexicon that enables us to distinguish easily among the many levels of complexity of B2B sales.

As you've noted, one major complexity for content marketers is related to the number of people who influence a buying decision. But more than that, it also depends on the number of business functions or domains that are involved.

Legal has their own priorities, concerns, and decision criteria. Finance has others. Compliance has others. Supply chain has others. And on and on.

The key is that you must create content that appeals to each of the key groups and that speaks to their varying values, concerns, perceptions of risk, and functional requirements.

elements.text:
Thanks for you insights. I agree with you entirely. I think part of the problem is that we have no concept in our marketing and sales lexicon that enables us to distinguish easily among the many levels of complexity of B2B sales.

As you've noted, one major complexity for content marketers is related to the number of people who influence a buying decision. But more than that, it also depends on the number of business functions or domains that are involved.

Legal has their own priorities, concerns, and decision criteria. Finance has others. Compliance has others. Supply chain has others. And on and on.

The key is that you must create content that appeals to each of the key groups and that speaks to their varying values, concerns, perceptions of risk, and functional requirements.

text: I think in the past marketers have pretty much quit producing content for deals that have been passed to Sales. They wash their hands when it comes to closing the deal. I believe this is a big missed opportunity for both Sales and Marketing.

elements.text: I think in the past marketers have pretty much quit producing content for deals that have been passed to Sales. They wash their hands when it comes to closing the deal. I believe this is a big missed opportunity for both Sales and Marketing.

text: Thanks guys that makes sense <@UUVRXEWJ1> <@URAV154AV> I’m thinking the place to start is hearing from the sales team on objections and questions they’ve heard

elements.text: I’m thinking the place to start is hearing from the sales team on objections and questions they’ve heard

text:
<@U013VC9V325> I think you’ve chosen a good place to start. 

I urge you to keep pressing the sales team to dig deeper for questions. 

They may share a few to get you off their backs. But you want them to share dozens of questions and concerns. 

To facilitate your conversations with Sales, I suggest you ask them to break the buyer questions down for different business functions involved in the buying decision. 

Then also break the questions and concerns down by the stage in the buyer’s decision process. (This is important because buyer interests and preoccupations vary by stage. You must share the right information with the right people at the right times and in the right formats.)

The more Sales shares such insights with you, the more you’ll be able to help Sales by creating content that speaks to buyers’ questions and concerns. 

Sellers need content for this because they’re rarely available to address the questions of all buyers at the time they arise. 

In addition, some key executives who influence a buying decision are likely to be unknown to the seller or they don’t want to talk to sellers in general.

As much as 70% of the complex buying decision occurs with no seller available to influence the buyers’ thought processes. 

It’s gotten even harder for sellers now that face-to-face sales meetings are limited because of the pandemic. Sellers have to rely more than ever on remote selling and digital content. And marketers have an opportunity to step up.

elements.text:
I think you’ve chosen a good place to start. 

I urge you to keep pressing the sales team to dig deeper for questions. 

They may share a few to get you off their backs. But you want them to share dozens of questions and concerns. 

To facilitate your conversations with Sales, I suggest you ask them to break the buyer questions down for different business functions involved in the buying decision. 

Then also break the questions and concerns down by the stage in the buyer’s decision process. (This is important because buyer interests and preoccupations vary by stage. You must share the right information with the right people at the right times and in the right formats.)

The more Sales shares such insights with you, the more you’ll be able to help Sales by creating content that speaks to buyers’ questions and concerns. 

Sellers need content for this because they’re rarely available to address the questions of all buyers at the time they arise. 

In addition, some key executives who influence a buying decision are likely to be unknown to the seller or they don’t want to talk to sellers in general.

As much as 70% of the complex buying decision occurs with no seller available to influence the buyers’ thought processes. 

It’s gotten even harder for sellers now that face-to-face sales meetings are limited because of the pandemic. Sellers have to rely more than ever on remote selling and digital content. And marketers have an opportunity to step up.
